{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3392113,"name":"Rose Dray","username":"Henbi3656","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/henbi3656/{size}/219418_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-26T07:08:30.607Z","cooked":"

We’ve seen a lot of different variations of wheel layouts for launchers this year. What has your team found to be the best for long range shooting this year? Some common setups Ive seen are the standard 2 wheels per quadrant (meaning 8 in total), 2 per quadrant but with 1 wheel missing from one quadrant, 2 per quadrant but with one slid over to the other side giving one quadrant 3 and one quadrant 1, 3 per quadrant, and so on.

Examples below

359 - 2 Per Quadrant one slid over

image1004×455 49.7 KB

581 - 2 per quadrant and an extra layer deep
image990×691 44.2 KB

254 - 3 per quadrant with one quadrant having smaller wheels and an extra layer deep
image664×633 45.7 KB

Our shooter used an entirely different method to achieve the spin we wanted. We had three stealth wheels in each quadrant, but used a single power source (paired Krakens) and a lot of transfer belts and gears to produce different flywheel rpms between the left two and right two quadrants. In the pic below you can just see the shooter Krakens at the bottom left, the long 15mm transfer belt that runs up to a pulley on the dead axle (also the shooter’s pivot) and then down to the left side flywheels and the transfer gears that run power through the indicated hex shaft and to the gears on the right side. Unlike everything else, which are at 1:1, that gear set is 30:36, thus slowing the right flywheels just a bit. It worked perfectly, giving us about 1 rotation per 3 meters of flight, which proved to be exactly what we needed for accuracy at distance.

Aquila shooter pic782×710 120 KB

sick, I had seen some teams do the slowing down one quadrant thing whether it was via code or mechanical parts and it was a really neat solution.

I think the generally agreed upon “best” setup is the 8x 4 inch deadaxled wheels, driven by double sided timing belt at a different speed on each side. To reduce note over definition, the faster side has cat tongue grip tape and the other side some sort of slippery material.

You can see examples on 1323, 4414 v2, 581, etc. The main disadvantage is that the package is quite large. 6036 has a great example of the setup that you can take a look at in their public cad.

We used conical wheels to achieve spin:

20240711_2325291809×1447 157 KB

20240711_2332151920×1440 305 KB

The compression of the NOTE is exactly the same on both sides. But the bigger wheels give the NOTE a higher linear velocity on that side, because same angular velocity x bigger circumference.
Which then creates spin.
